title: Limitations to photosynthesis by proton motive force-induced photosystem II photodamage
abstract: The thylakoid proton motive force (<italic>pmf</italic>) generated during photosynthesis is the essential driving force for ATP production; it is also a central regulator of light capture and electron transfer. We investigated the effects of elevated <italic>pmf</italic> on photosynthesis in a library of <italic>Arabidopsis thaliana</italic> mutants with altered rates of thylakoid lumen proton efflux, leading to a range of steady-state <italic>pmf</italic> extents. We observed the expected <italic>pmf-</italic>dependent alterations in photosynthetic regulation, but also strong effects on the rate of photosystem II (PSII) photodamage. Detailed analyses indicate this effect is related to an elevated electric field (Δ<italic>ψ</italic>) component of the <italic>pmf</italic>, rather than lumen acidification, which <italic>in vivo</italic> increased PSII charge recombination rates, producing singlet oxygen and subsequent photodamage. The effects are seen even in wild type plants, especially under fluctuating illumination, suggesting that Δ<italic>ψ</italic>-induced photodamage represents a previously unrecognized limiting factor for plant productivity under dynamic environmental conditions seen in the field.
